_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



At the Edge Moor Plant near Wilmington, Delaware, we follow the DuPont Commitment to Safety, Health, and Environmental excellence.  

-    We will conduct our business with respect and care for the environment

-    We will continuously improve our practices in light of advances in technology and new understandings in safety, health, and environmental science

-    We will adhere to the highest standards for the safe operation and the protection of our environment, our employees, our customers, and the people in our community

-    We will strengthen our business by making S/H/E issues an integral part of our business activities, and by striving to align our business with public expectations

-    We believe that all injuries, occupational illnesses, and incidents are preventable, and our Commitment is Zero

-    We will be prepared for emergencies, and will provide leadership to assist our local communities in emergency preparedness



The Edge Moor site uses a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to ensure the safety of our employees and the public, and protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive process safety and risk management activities that we have implemented: 

-    A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation

-    An overview of our accidental release prevention programs

-    A 5-year accident history involving releases of chemicals covered by EPA's RMP rule

-    An overview of our emergency response program

-    The certifications that EPA's RMP rule requires us to provide

-    The detailed information (called data elements) about our risk management program



2.0     FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The DuPont Edge Moor facility produces Titanium dioxide (TiO2), an inorganic pigment used to create opacity in paint, paper, and plastics.  It is produced a

t the Edge Moor site using the chloride process.  Titanium-bearing ore, chlorine, and petroleum coke are combined to produce titanium tetrachloride.  The titanium tetrachloride is subsequently oxidized to titanium dioxide.  The Edge Moor site process also produces ferric chloride as a co-product, which is used in wastewater treatment applications.



The following RMP-covered Hazardous Materials are used at the Edge Moor site:

-    Chlorine (Cl2)

-    Titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4)

-    Phosphorus TriChloride (PCl3)



3.0     GENERAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



DuPont takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  DuPont was an originator of the Process Safety Management (PSM) framework, which formed the basis of the OSHA 1910.119 PSM standard in 1992 (and later the EPA's RMP standard).  



Edge Moor's management systems address each of the key features of successful PSM programs, including:

-    Process Safety Information (i.e. Process Technology)

-    Process Hazard Analysis

-    Operating Procedures and Safe Work Practices (including hot work)

-    Training and Performance

-    Mechanical Integrity

-    Quality Assurance

-    Management of Change (technology and subtle)

-    Pre-startup Safety Review

-    Compliance Audits

-    Incident Investigation and Reporting

-    Employee participation

-    Contractors (safety, training and performance)

-    Management of Change- Personnel

-    Emergency Planning and Response



These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  In addition, DuPont has internal policies and standards that exceed OSHA and EPA regulations in the implementation of Process Safety Management.  We use first-and second-party audits to review performance trends, identify non-conformances with standards, and drive continuous improvement.  We have leading and lagging indicators of PSM performance, which are reviewed quarterly with top

corporate leadership.  We have strong Leadership and Employee involvement to ensure that management systems are operating effectively and concerns are surfaced and addressed.  Edge Moor utilizes a comprehensive corrective action tracking system to manage and document actions taken to improve process safety performance.  



The Edge Moor site is also covered by DuPont's corporate standards for Management of Highly Toxic Materials (for Cl2, TiCl4, and PCl3).  These are mandatory standards covering the entire range of hazardous materials handling, including equipment design, materials of construction, supplier and customer auditing, operating and maintenance procedures, training, process controls, leak detection and mitigation, and emergency response.  These standards also provide for additional 2nd-party auditing by corporate highly toxic material experts.  



4.0     FIVE- YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Edge Moor site keeps records for all chemical releases that occur at the facility.  There were no significant accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past 5 years.  

-    There have been no lost workday injuries to Edge Moor employees or contractors involving process chemicals at Edge Moor within the past 5 years

-    The employee injuries reported in our accident history typically involve small, localized exposures to process chemicals where medical treatment and/or work medication was provided

-    There have been no off-site chemical exposure incidents within the past 5 years



5.0     EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Edge Moor site maintains an emergency response plan, which meets all the requirements stated in the RMP rule.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Edge Moor maintains an on-site emergency response team with round the clock coverage for potential release scenarios.  



Furthermore, we coord

inate our plan with the community emergency responders.  Edge Moor has strong working partnerships with the local responders such as Brandywine Hundred Fire Company, Delaware state police, New Castle County LEPC, DNREC, and mutual aid groups such as the New Castle County Hazmat team (NCCIHMRA).  Joint training programs are periodically conducted.    



Delaware Emergency Management Agency (DEMA) in partnership with the LEPC operates an advanced Emergency Notification System including auto-dialer for specific locations, multi-media emergency alerts, and inter-agency response capability.  DuPont Edge Moor supports DEMA and LEPC with resources, advisory input, and emergency responders.  Our program is detailed in our Edge Moor Emergency Procedure Manual. 





6.0     PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Edge Moor plant, like all DuPont facilities, is committed to continuous improvement in process safety and risk management.  Significant upgrades have been recently adopted and are planned for the future, including:

-    Conducting an annual site PSM program review covering key criteria for evaluation to drive continuous improvement and leadership involvement

-    Requirement for periodic review of Standard Operating Conditions (SOC) to ensure focus, including an understanding of the source or rationale  (tied back to consequence analysis)                                                                                                                                                                                  

-    Clarification of requirements to review process design basis (process technology package) every 5 years as part of cyclic PHA preparations and associated documentation

-    Extensive revision of equipment lists for Process Technology (PT) to clarify requirements (prescriptive, consequence based, prevention/mitigation systems) 

-    Added requirement to verify effectiveness of PHA  and Incident Investigation recommendations

-    Updated procedures to address Alar

m Management, Procedures for Shift Turnover, Recording SIS Demands, Leak reporting/repair, Controls for Isolation (intervening) valves in relief systems, and Lone Worker administrative controls 

-    Revision of Equipment lists for Quality Assurance (QA) including the addition of key equipment components for QA beyond PSM critical listings 

-    Added requirement for Pre Start-up Safety Reviews to verify that installation is in compliance with local regulatory requirements and operating permits

-    Major updates to security processes and systems to meet CFATS (Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard) Requirements
